body:
Ok. So I have found a workaround. If I add ignoreSynchronization and sleep for a while I can make the test pass. Like so:

it('should show right profile', (done) => {
  browser.ignoreSynchronization = true;                                 <--
  utils.loginAndGoTo('home/user').then(() => {
    sleep(1000);                                                        <--
    expect(element(by.css('home p')).getText()).toContain('user');
    done();
  }, (e) => { console.error('error in home.component.e2e-spec.ts', e); });
});

I can't figure out why this makes it work though. Somehow my util method (which is asynchronous) makes protractor believe it has to wait for angular? Additionally I can now use browser.getCurrentUrl instead of browser.driver.getCurrentUrl. Here is what the documentation for ignoreSynchronization says

/**
   * If true, Protractor will not attempt to synchronize with the page before
   * performing actions. This can be harmful because Protractor will not wait
   * until $timeouts and $http calls have been processed, which can cause
   * tests to become flaky. This should be used only when necessary, such as
   * when a page continuously polls an API using $timeout.
   *
   * @type {boolean}
   */
title: Mysterious protractor test failure when using custom util
